answers.answer: I have to leave that to your discretion.  I can answer general questions but advising people on when they should receive care without being able to interact would be dangerous.Palpitations with a structurally normal heart are rarely dangerous.  If you have concerns, you should call you doctor to see if they think you should be seen sooner.

question: I am 44, female, and on four meds for HTN.  I am also diabetic and on oral meds, along with various other medical issues (hypothyroid, controlled, for instance).Last night I had a sudden onset of palpitations, with the "missed/skipped beat" coming about 5-15 times per minute.  My bp was not terribly high, at around 140's/90's, but I did feel light headed and "strange" during this time.  I had just eaten popcorn a while before and my bg was elevated at 198.  I drank some water and took a scheduled potassium supplement a bit early (10meq), but the palps continued for over an hour.  I finally went to bed and when I woke up during the night they were still there, but gone in the morning.I have recently changed from Metformin 100 mg x 2, to Coreg 25 mf x 2, and I also take Adalat 60mg, Lisinopril 20 mg and Micardis 80mg.  I take Metformin 850 x 3, Januvia 100mg (only for about the last two weeks) and just started on Avandia 4 mg for diabetes.  My other meds are for thyroid, GERD, potassium, generalized dystonia (levodopa).Is this something I should be concerned about?  I see my doctor in a week and a half, but do I need to contact her before then if this happens again?ThanksRamona
title: Sudden onset of palpitations
